title: Before 1 November 2017, will the US impose economic sanctions on Iran for activities related to a nuclear program?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Downgrading further. Congress now has to counter-balance Trump acting tough. No matter how much the GOP opposed the deal in the past, they don't want ANOTHER hotspot right now.

U.S. House of Representatives were to vote this week on new sanctions on Iran’s ballistic missiles program. The House passed sanctions on Hezbollah but appeared  no motion was passed on the topic of Iran sanctions. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-congress/u-s-house-to-vote-on-non-nuclear-iran-sanctions-next-week-idUSKBN1CP2A7
http://clerk.house.gov/floorsummary/floor.aspx
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Not enough time left. 
Congress has 60 days to put new sanctions together to potentially impose at that time....takes us past Nov.

Dateline 10-15-2017  "We're going to stay in," Tillerson said in an interview with CNN's Jake Tapper on "State of the Union," though he left open the possibility that the US could seek another agreement. --Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said Sunday the US is trying to stay in the Iran nuclear deal while hoping to achieve more from it, days after President Donald Trump threatened to pull the US out of the agreement.
He handed it off to congress. I predict nothing happens, to great fan fare.
I still think this is doubtful even with the current situation of decertification that Trump has created.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/trump-expected-move-iran-nuclear-deal-171013054108898.html
The Twitmeister is planning to quack and flap, but will leave it up to the paralyzed legislative branch to do anything.  Even if they manage to do something, it will not be in time for this deadline.  More late-night Twits can be expected.
Trump expected to decertify around October 15,  but Congress would have to impose sanctions.

Maintaining forecast:
“A senior administration official said on Friday that the U.S. president would not seek the reimposition of broad sanctions that would risk collapsing the accord. But Mr. Trump is expected to announce new measures, including the prospect of additional targeted sanctions, the designation of the Revolutionary Guard Corps as a terrorist organisation and the adoption of a tougher stance on Iranian provides in Syria, Iraq and Yemen.” 
If the administration official’s statement is correct in that they are trying to avoid collapsing the agreement, Trump cannot impose economic sanctions on Iran for activities relating to a nuclear program without violating the JCPOA.

It looks like the US prez will decertify, although it is still barely possible that one of the grownups may persuade him otherwise.  In any case it is unlikely that the Congress will play along; even if they do, they won't get to it before this Q expires.

Dateline 10-5-2017 President Trump is expected to overrule his top national security advisers and decline to certify the Iran nuclear agreement, according to people who have been briefed on the matter, a decision that would reopen a volatile political debate on Iran but is likely to leave in place the landmark deal negotiated by the Obama administration.
Trump to decertify.  60 days to decide to reimpose sanctions .  Won't rush that.

President Donald Trump is expected to announce soon that he will decertify the landmark international deal to curb Iran’s nuclear program, a senior administration official said on Thursday, in a step that potentially could cause the 2015 accord to unravel.

Trump plans to decertify... the ball has bounced into congress' court (if the reports turn out to be accurate). 
"Tillerson has said the problem with the JCPOA is not the JCPOA," one senior administration official said, using the acronym for the 2015 nuclear deal, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action.
"It's the legislation," the official said. "Every 90 days the president must certify and its creates a political crisis. If the administration could put the nuclear deal in a corner, everyone could happily get back to work on dealing with everything else that is a problem with Iran."
 (http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/05/politics/trump-iran-deal-deadline-plan/index.html?adkey=bn) 
I think the gist of it is that the administration doesn't want to certify every 90 days, so its a problem on the U.S. end - and Iran is still compliant.

Trump is being theatrical regarding the Iran nuclear deal. He's made a secret decision and we get to be in suspense until -- when? Rumor holds it will be Oct. 12.  Is there enough time from Oct. 12 to close of this question Nov. 1 to impose or reimpose sanctions?
Source: Dateline 10-4-2017 https://www.apnews.com/e726f1c5747b434a912a3a896d6a4fbe/Nuke-deal-hangs-in-balance-as-Trump-plans-Iran-policy-speech

Trump is looking for a reason to scrap the Iran Nuclear deal but is having a tough time finding a valid reason and thus far has only been able to say they are violating ‘the spirit of the deal’. 
 The Trump administration extended sanctions relief on Thursday, Sept. 14 but the waiver must be renewed every 120 days which next falls on October 15. Trump is threatening action and to scrap the deal; even if without due cause there is a possibility that he will not re-certify. 
However, if he does not re-certify the deal then Congress has 60 days to re-impose suspended sanctions.   A battle in Congress would likely ensue and any possible reinstated sanctions would likely not take effect before Nov. 1.  Also, Europe is prepared to block sanctions re-imposed by the U.S., and they have a statute allowing them to do so.  While the U.S. may attempt to re-impose sanctions, it is doubtful that this will be accomplished.

The US may impose some more sanctions and claim it's on account of "activities related to a nuclear program: but not a direct violation of the nukes deal.  They will do this because if they claim it's down to a violation of the deal, the US Congress will have to act and there is little chance of that.
Not sure Trump can do this, but he will push very hard for it after missile test

M. Petits-Doigts, having decided he has achieved a great triumph with the announced new sanctions against the DPRK, may very well decide to overreach here.  Ignorance is its own reward, so stay tuned.  Going up, but only from 1 to 2.

Still not quite sure what M. Petits-Doigts will do with the October cert.  All the adults in the world want one outcome,  but he is so far been pretty much impervious to adult supervision.  There are persistent hopeful rumours that he is about to go through intellectual puberty, but these have been circulating for well over a year now, to no result.

This is unlikely when all the attention is on NK

This decision will be heavily influenced by the situation in the DPRK.  President Trump is a wild-card, and he may decide that DPRK's export of nuclear technology must be limited at all ends of the supply chain.  Since DPRK gets funding from Iran, this might be a valid way to execute diplomatic options.
Doubtful in the current political climate that congressional support for new sanctions could be achieved in the near future.
I think k whatever the administrations does about NK will be the vehicle to signal Iran now.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Rhetoric may flair but the adults will not let this happen.
Iran is prohibiting inspection of several of its nuclear sites.  Very likely this will lead to sanctions.   Less likely all this will get done by 1 November.

Dateline Aug. 29, 2017  Former U.S.ambassador to the U.N., John Bolton -- a major hawk when it comes to dealing with Iran -- has been shut out of the White House under the new leadership of chief of staff John Kelly. FP’s Dan De Luce writes that several sources confirm Bolton’s regular meetings with Trump are a thing of the past, and he has been unable to deliver a plan he devised to get Washington out of the deal it signed with Tehran to halt that country’s nuclear program. -- 	Foreign Policy <fp@foreignpolicy.com>
Iran rejects U.S. demand for U.N. visit to military sites

Dateline Aug. 28, 2017 -- Within days, international monitors will send an inspection report on Iran’s nuclear facilities to governments around the world, touching off a chain of events that could lead to another clash between President Trump and congressional Republicans, or even his own top advisers.

Lowering forecast: I think it’s unlikely Trump will place sanctions on Iran for nuclear-related activity, other scenarios such as the administration walking away due to Iran allegedly violating the ‘spirt of the agreement’ would be more likely. 
“Nikki Haley suggested that Iran’s past practice of using military sites for covert nuclear development work was grounds for suspicion. But Laura Rockwood, a former legal counsel in the IAEA’s safeguards department (which carries out inspections), said the US or any other member state would have to provide solid and contemporaneous evidence to trigger an inspection” (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/28/iran-nuclear-deal-violations-white-house-search-intelligence) 
Plus “general consensus among U.S. intelligence and foreign intelligence agenices, the state department, the IAEA and the other 5 countries that signed the JCPOA along with the EU, that there is no significant evidence that Iran has violated its obligations under the deal” (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/28/iran-nuclear-deal-violations-white-house-search-intelligence) 
Haley also said: “We don’t know if he’s [Trump] going to certify or decertify the deal” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-usa-idUSKCN1B22JZ) 
It’s possible Trump will withhold certifying Iran’s compliance until all sites have been inspected - but I’m unaware as to whether he can legally do this.

The Trump admin seem to be doing all the can to revoke the deal, but their track record of following up on policy targets is non-existent. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/28/iran-nuclear-deal-violations-white-house-search-intelligence
The US has several stupid options available before it exercises this one.  Stay tuned, though.
Iran has violated the terms of the agreement, but the foreign policy establishment has too much invested in keeping the deal current. Almost 50/50.
Feel it is pretty clear: US will continue to impose sanctions regarding Iran's nuclear activity and Iran would love to pull out of it.

The Iranians are threatening to pull out of the nukes deal if sanctions proceed.  That is pretty much what President Littlefingers wants, but the Iranians know this better than he does.  I think they are smarter than that, so I'm only coming up to 2 from 1.  I fully expect to be sorry about this, one way or the other.
In the real world this would be zero.  We don't live there any more, so hedging a bit

“U.S. ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, will travel to Vienna later this month to discuss Iran’s nuclear activities with UN atomic watchdog officials, a U.S. official said, as part of Washington’s review of Tehran’s compliance with the JCPOA” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-usa-idUSKBN1AP2AR)

At this juncture in time, reimposing sanctions on Iran is likely much lower on the list of the President's priorities compared to when he was campaigning for the Presidency.  Reacting to high levels of aggression from the DPRK, as well as serious problems with Russia are enough to fill President Trump's appetite for conflict.  Iran will surely become a needed foe for this administration, but not likely before November of this year.

The current administration may try to push some sanctions after getting the travel ban to be partially implemented by the Supreme Court's judgement, but I suspect that any efforts to push more sanctions will be swallowed up by all the distractions that the current administration seems to be creating for itself.

(https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/05/25/senate-committee-approves-added-sanctions-iran/102149522/) 
If the Trump administration continues to impose new sanctions on Iran it could annoy Iran to the point that they decide it is no longer worth curbing their nuclear program due to getting little in return. It was clear in Iran’s presidential elections that neither Rouhani or his opponents are seeing the economic improvement that they hoped the JCPOA would provide - it was a key campaign issue. 
New sanctions, along with the fact that some sanctions under the agreement still remain; “those remaining are still discouraging European banks from providing desperately needed financing for business deals and infrastructure projects in Iran” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/28/world/middleeast/iran-nuclear-deal-hassan-rouhani-donald-trump.html?_r=0) will continue to be a deterrent to foreign banks.
I've moved this only because of Trump. But I believe there are too many other concerns that are at his doorstep. This one won't get more sanctions.

Updating. Downgrading my prediction. It looks like Trump has too many fish to fry. My previous prediction that the Trump administration would conflate the various reasons to sanction Iran hasn't proved true. In fact, Trump hasn't been nearly as aggressive to the rest of the world as I predicted. Maybe because it was all talk to win the election. Maybe it's a shift his perception and thinking. Maybe it's something else. In any case, this looks less likely to happen.

I think Rouhani's reelection rules out an expanded nuclear program for two reasons. First is that he is the deal's main defender and has nothing to gain by undermining his main diplomatic achievement. Second is that he doesn't need to, Iranian influence is already spreading across the region and some arms sales and kind words by a distracted American president don't change the underlying strategic balance of the Middle East.

The recent speech made by Trump in Riyadh singled out Iran as a driving force of terrorism in the region - they will likely retaliate with nuclear tests to gain some needed leverage, to which we will impose/reinforce sanctions.

This is an issue that has varied opinions of eventual outcome. One way of looking at this is to see Iran as really 2 countries: a country based on commerce and another based on a military-Theocracy. My forecast is based on the speculation that international commerce will be of greater behavioral value than the behavior of weapons development, that the country will be finding that it benefits more with commercial activities among countries than it would be with activities related to a nuclear program.

The prospect of dealing with a nuclear crisis, let alone two at once, is likely enough to keep the United States in the JCPOA, so long as Iran continues to adhere to its terms. Furthermore, its withdrawal from the Iranian deal would undermine the United States' efforts to draw other aspiring nuclear powers, namely North Korea, to the negotiating table.

https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/us-reviews-its-stance-iran?utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=article
Keeping sanctions at bay is still a priority for Iran, and one the impending elections will not threaten. The current electoral process has so far proved to be as carefully managed and orchestrated as ever. Iran's Guardian Council made sure during the vetting process that the vote would be free of surprises, sidelining the entire populist faction by disqualifying former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and weeding out candidates who would challenge the establishment's authority. As a result, much of Iran's foreign and security policy will remain in place no matter who wins the upcoming vote. And for now, the country's leaders are more invested in shoring up the domestic economy than in building a nuclear bomb.

I concur with some other forecasters who seem to believe that the Trump administration is on a mission to pick a fight with Iran. My current forecast assumes that "activities related to a nuclear program" must fall under the JCPOA dispute mechanism. I'm curious if others feel this is a reasonable assumption, or if they see ways in which such nuclear related sanctions could fall outside of the JCPOA.

New sanctions that the Trump administration imposed on Friday to punish Tehran’s latest ballistic missile test marked the beginning of what officials called the end of an era in which the United States was “too tolerant of Iran’s bad behavior.”
In what was described as the first in a series of efforts to confront Iran around the globe, the ban on banking transfers was levied against 25 Iranians and companies that officials said assisted in Tehran’s ballistic missile program and support of terrorist groups.
The immediate trigger for the sanctions, which drew from a list of targets drawn up last year by the Obama administration, was Iran’s missile test last Sunday. 
In announcing the new sanctions, the White House made clear that it planned to call out every violation, and respond. 
Even inside the White House it is unclear how much further, beyond sanctions, President Trump is willing to take the confrontation. While he suggested during his campaign that he might scrap the nuclear deal, which he described as a “disaster,”
Jim Mattis, and Rex W. Tillerson, made clear during their confirmation hearings that the world was better off with the accord, for the next decade at least, because of its prohibitions on Iran amassing enough enriched uranium or separated plutonium to manufacture even a single nuclear weapon.
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/03/us/politics/iran-sanctions-trump.html

As I see it, there are two ways for this question to resolve to a Yes answer. First, Iran could actually carry out nuclear-related activity that leads to sanctions being imposed. Second, a foreign power could fabricate evidence that makes it appear that Iran has carried out nuclear-related activity. I think the odds of Iran carrying out nuclear-related activity during Rouhani's term are very small (1%), and I think the odds that Rouhani will be re-elected in May 2017 are very good (75%) based on his popular approval, working relationship with Khamenei, and Iran's growing GDP. I think the odds that a principalist will be elected are about 20%, and the odds that such a person would undertake nuclear-related activity in violation of the JCPOA before November 2017 are about 20%. So I calculate the odds for the first route to the outcome as roughly 5%. The second route is trickier. Trump does not seem to care for US intelligence analysis, which suggests that his team will want direct access to unprocessed intelligence. That intelligence could be loaded with false leads from states inimical to Iran, or from Iranian groups in exile that want to overthrow the current regime. I think amateur sleuths tend to weigh evidence on the basis of its emotional impact, so it may not be difficult to convince the Trump administration that Iran is undertaking a secret nuclear program (similar to the way Bush was led to believe Iraq had a WMD program). I put the odds at 80% that Trump will believe Iran is "up to something nuclear", and another 70% that Congress will go along with him. In order for sanctions to be effective, Trump would need to convince at least a few other members of the P5+1. China won't go along with it for economic reasons, and I don't think Germany will either as things stand now. Russia won't go along with it because of the post-Arab-Spring political bloc I think they are building in the Middle East, but they would be happy to see us shoot ourselves in the foot economically and strategically, so they won't stop us. That leaves France, where Le Pen might win, and the UK, where Iran is still not very popular. I think the odds of pulling together a coalition of right-leaning nations by November 2017 to impose sanctions are fair, maybe 30%. That makes the odds of the second route completing by November 2017 about 17%. Overall, I put odds of a "Yes" outcome by November 2017 at about 22%.

First of all, the agreement has some fairly robust stipulations that severely limit enrichment levels and make it very difficult for Iran to get away with anything for long. Since we monitor the flow of nuclear materials, we will know if some are being diverted from the stream, concentrated in an area, etc. Also, there are preliminary judicial measures involving a bipartisan committee that will be put into play if there is suspicion of wrongdoing. In any case, even if Iran though it were worthwhile to disobey the agreement, new sanctions wouldn't be enacted immediately.

Hopefully, GJ differentiates the recent sanction EXTENSION bill from the actualization of sanctions. Under the current sanction framework, sanctions are authorized, but the Secretary of State suspends them as long as Iran does not violate its side of the nuclear agreement. The recent extension "simply" continues that framework. So, in my view, "impose" means the Secretary of State allows the sanctions to be actualized; or, that Congress adds new sanctions outside the framework.

Putting together a set of sanctions is a complex internal and external process. It involves not only some consensus among domestic policymakers, but in order to be effective you need the cooperation of global allies. Just one of these task alone would be a heavy lift for a newly elected President. The so called "snapback" provisions contained within in the JCPOA dictate that an allegation be made by a P5+1state and then Iran would have an opportunity to correct any actions/behavior that violated the agreement. This is only step one and step two. Too little time.

Imposing nuclear sanctions would involve coordination across a couple of fronts (US legislative branch; potentially UN and other international stakeholders).  Would need some clear proof or drivers (not sure if non-conformity with recent Iranian agreement itself would be enough).
